speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air_] To start off the second hour, I would like to depart from my usual format because I recently read a book that... well, it truly just knocked my mental socks off.  It's called "The Menopausal Male," and its author, the distinguished psychiatric scholar Dr. Helmut Bruga, has graciously agreed to join us today from his offices at the University of Washington.  Dr. Bruga, guten tag.  I've been an admirer of yours for a long time.

speaker: Bruga
text: [_v.o._] Thank you. I enjoy your show as well.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Bruga
text: Yes.  Though I do not in most cases agree with your analysis.

speaker: Frasier
text: Back to your book.  Now, we're all very familiar with the changes in the female menopause, but your research indicates...

speaker: Bruga
text: Excuse me, Dr. Crane.  May I say hello to Roz?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, of course.

speaker: Bruga
text: Hello, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Hello, Dr. Bruga.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, your research indicates that the reproductive imperative is re-awakened in later life, when the man is...

speaker: Bruga
text: You have a very sensuous voice.

speaker: Frasier
text: ...Thank you.

speaker: Bruga
text: Not you, Roz.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes well, back to male menopause.

speaker: Bruga
text: Would you perhaps like to go to a movie or something, maybe grab a bite?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, that would be very...

speaker: Roz
text: No.  No, thank you very much.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, our time has just flown by.  Thank you for joining us, Dr. Bruga, and for so vividly proving your point.

speaker: Bruga
text: You will give Roz my number?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I think Roz has your number! **SITTING PRETTY** _Scene Two - Apartment The doorbell bing-bongs and Daphne answers.  It's Niles._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.  I hope I haven't come at a bad time.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, your brother isn't home from work yet, and your father's out walking Eddie.

speaker: Niles
text: [_entering_] Oh, darn the luck.  I, ah, I stopped by to drop this off. [_holds up a jewelry case_] It's a necklace I bought for Maris, I was hoping to hide it here until her birthday.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I'm sure it'll be all right.  Mind if I have a peek?

speaker: Niles
text: Not at all. _He opens the case and flicks the necklace into Daphne's hand, stealing a glance down her cleavage as she catches it._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, my - emeralds.  Your practice must be doing awfully well. Who'd have thought the mentally disturbed had this much money?

speaker: Niles
text: Would you like to try it on?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I'd love to.  If you don't think Mrs. Crane would mind.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, certainly not.  Maris is the soul of generosity.  Just last week she donated all her old cocktail dresses to a homeless shelter.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, let me just get me hair out of the way.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, here we go... _As Niles attempts to close the catch, the necklace slips (accidentally?) from his fingers and drops down the front of Daphne's blouse._

speaker: Niles/Daphne
text: Oh, dear!/OOH!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, my. [_puts hand down top and starts fishing for the necklace_] Can you see them?

speaker: Niles
text: [_looking_] Oh yes, thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_deadpan_] Hello, Niles.  Whatever are you doing here?

speaker: Niles
text: I, um, bought an emerald necklace for Maris, and I needed some place to hide it for her birthday.

speaker: Frasier
text: Emeralds?  Well, may I see it?

speaker: Niles
text: Not at the moment, no.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why not?

speaker: Daphne
text: It's down me blouse.

speaker: Frasier
text: I see.  Well, I'm sure Maris will never think of looking for it there.

speaker: Daphne
text: It slipped down there when I was trying it on.  I'll just go extract it.

speaker: Niles
text: Just call me butterfingers.

speaker: Frasier
text: Join a health club, Niles.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, guys.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, Dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hi, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, Niles.  What brings you by?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, Maris's birthday.  I'm hiding her gift here.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it's getting that time again, huh?  Well, I guess I'm gonna have to get her something.  It's too bad, I just got back from the hardware store.  Saw a great-looking ratchet set.

speaker: Frasier
text: As if there's anything left on her that needs tightening.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Dad, no, no!  Not more duct tape!

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah. [_applying a length to The Chair_] I gotta repair a little split in the old throne here.  You gotta catch these rips early, or they look like hell.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Dad, instead of repairing this old relic all the time, why don't we just bring the Eames down here?

speaker: Martin
text: Ah no, that thing's too fancy for me, I just need a comfortable place to park my fanny. [_starts towards bedroom_]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sotto voce_] How about Florida?

speaker: Martin
text: I heard that.

speaker: Frasier
text: God, you know, when you think of all the care I put into decorating my home, only to have it mocked by this atrocity.

speaker: Niles
text: The bottom line is, it is your home.  Why don't you just make him get rid of it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes well, it's not as simple as all that.  I mean, one would have to find the appropriate moment.  I mean, Dad does have his feelings, and one should consider those, and he has quite an attachment to this little chair...

speaker: Niles
text: You're afraid to stand up to him, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, like you're not.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, at least I don't have to live with something unattractive. _Frasier shoots Niles a look from under raised eyebrows.  Niles, taking his meaning, looks offended._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, Niles, I'm just having some fun with you.  Actually, I think Maris is rather attractive - in a, a minimalist sort of way. [_then_] Oh, forget it, I'm just upset about the chair.

speaker: Niles
text: You know, Frasier, there is a perfectly sound psychological basis for getting rid of this chair.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, really?  Well, enlighten me, doctor.

speaker: Niles
text: With pleasure.  Originally, Dad needed it to bridge the transition from his old apartment to life here with you. But as with all transitional objects - be they a teddy bear, be they a thumb, be they a blankie, be they a chair...

speaker: Frasier
text: Stop saying "Be they!"

speaker: Niles
text: The point is, there comes a time when the healthy thing is to put these security objects aside and reassert your independence.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, of course.  So what you're saying is that if I should, say, go down to the store and buy Dad a new chair, throw this one in the trash heap, I wouldn't be doing it for me, I'd be doing it for him.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  And it would be a nice payback for the day he used your blankie to clean his service revolver. [_looks at watch_] Oops, I'm sorry, our time is up. **GOOD VIBRATIONS** _Scene Three - Furniture Store, Recliner Section Frasier and Niles are strangers in a strange land._

speaker: Niles
text: Dear God, Frasier, we've stumbled upon Hell's waiting room.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, now this is not a moment for the faint of heart. We're treading a thin line here, Niles. We've got to find something that compliments my decor as well as fulfills Dad's requirements.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear God.  Can you imagine anyone would have something like that in their living room?

speaker: Niles
text: It looks like someone upholstered it in golf pants.

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me, perhaps you could help us here.

speaker: Salesman
text: [_not stopping_] Yeah, perhaps.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we're looking for a chair.

speaker: Salesman
text: [_still not stopping_] We got 'em.

speaker: Frasier
text: Wait, wait-wait-wait! [_the salesman stops_]

speaker: Niles
text: Ideally, we're looking for something with the presence of a Mies van der Rohe and the playful insouciance of an early Le Corbusier.

speaker: Salesman
text: [_pointing to chair at random_] This one vibrates.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes well, perhaps you could direct us to your recliners, preferably one in suede.

speaker: Salesman
text: People seem to like this "Lazy-guy."

speaker: Frasier
text: "Lazy-guy."  I wonder what they call the deluxe model?  The "Hopeless Slack-Ass?"

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, hey.  Well, what about this one over here? [_points to leather recliner_]

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I-I hate to admit it, but that would not look altogether hideous in my living room.

speaker: Salesman
text: Have a seat.  This one's got Swedish massage.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, ha, no thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Go ahead, Niles.  Try it out.

speaker: Salesman
text: I'll fire it up for you.

speaker: Niles
text: [_dusting chair before sitting_] That won't be necessary. I like to sit in my chair, I don't really like to vibrate very much.  No, thank you any- [_the salesman switches it on_] Wha-hey.... ahh... ooh...

speaker: Salesman
text: It also has shiatsu. [_alters controls_]

speaker: Niles
text: OHHH... I never knew a chair could be this satisfying... I never knew that anything could.  I want it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right, Niles.  I'm sure it would fit right in with all of Maris's 18th-century antiques.

speaker: Niles
text: Well then, I'll just rent it an apartment and visit it on the side.

speaker: Salesman
text: So what do you think?  Why don't you have a try yourself?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I don't really think that's necessary.  You see, I'm buying it for my father..

speaker: Niles
text: No, no.  You've got to sit in it.

speaker: Frasier
text: And who knows about other people's tastes..

speaker: Niles
text: You can't make a decision before you sit in it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Something seems as if it's not quite right, [_sits_] really, I just... whoa... OH, MOMMY! _Scene Four - Apartment Eddie is barking loudly._

speaker: Frasier
text: Eddie?  What is the matter with him?

speaker: Daphne
text: He saw your father's chair was gone, and he's afraid it means your father's gone too.  I think he suspects foul play.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Eddie_] Oh, stop it!  If I had stuck Dad's feet into a bucket of cement and thrown him into Puget Sound, you would have been the tiny little splash that followed him!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh. that must be Leo. Wait'll you see this. _He opens the door for Leo, a surfer type dude, who has the new chair on a dolly._

speaker: Frasier
text: Come on in.

speaker: Leo
text: Dr. Crane, make way.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, now just be careful now, Leo.  Watch the furniture and the walls.

speaker: Leo
text: Excuse me, but I happen to be a professional.  I take a lot of pride in my work, and I would never-

speaker: Leo
text: Whoa... how'd that get there?  Hey look, at least I didn't lose my license this time, right?

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, all right.  Quickly, quickly.  I'm sure Beavis will start to wonder where you are.

speaker: Daphne
text: Actually Leo, as long as you're here, we're having a problem with a leaky faucet in the sink.

speaker: Leo
text: And where would that be?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_as if to a child_] In the kitchen, dear.

speaker: Leo
text: Hey, that wasn't a dumb question.  You got bathrooms too, dontcha?

speaker: Daphne
text: None that you'll be going anywhere near.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_re: chair_] Oh, Dr Crane, it's lovely.  Well, I thought the other one was nice, but this is smashing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, try it out, try it out.  And it has a little surprise.

speaker: Daphne
text: This is comfy.  Although it's a little on the soft side. I prefer... [_Frasier switches it on_] Hello... ohh... ohh... ohh... this is enough to make me give up me search for a meaningful relationship.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, quick, quick, that's Dad.  Get out, get out, get out. [_pulls Daphne out of chair_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, all right.  Just like a man -- now you've had your fun, you don't care where I am!

speaker: Martin
text: [_entering_] Hey, there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Dad.  I've ah, got a little surprise for you.

speaker: Martin
text: What's that?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's your new easy chair.

speaker: Martin
text: Well... what do you know about that?  Where's my old chair?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's down in the storage space.  Come on, try this one out.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh look, I appreciate this, Frasier.  But that - it, it... it really isn't me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, Dad, you haven't even sat in it yet.  Come on, come on, come on down, Martin Crane.

speaker: Martin
text: That's disgusting!  No, no look, Frasier, I'm sorry, but I'm a creature of habit and I think that I'd rather have my old chair back.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well Dad, but why?  I mean this chair's a lot more comfortable than the old one, and it's, it's therapeutic as well.

speaker: Martin
text: I know.  It's, I just never cared for leather, you know?  You stick to it in the hot weather, you can't sit in it in your shorts, it makes my back sweat.  Black's hot.  I, I, I, I'm sorry, I just couldn't get used to this chair.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right Dad, fine.  The important thing is that you lived with it for a full fifteen seconds.  Leo!

speaker: Daphne
text: Leo, we need you to bring Mr. Crane's chair back in here.

speaker: Leo
text: [_entering from kitchen_] Ah, no can do, fish n'chips.  Someone took it.

speaker: Martin
text: What?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you saying that someone broke into my storage space and stole my father's chair?

speaker: Leo
text: Your storage space?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's where I told you to put it.  You did put it there, didn't you?

speaker: Leo
text: Oh, man.  Not another day like last Tuesday.

speaker: Martin
text: Where's my chair, Leo?

speaker: Leo
text: I took it down to the dumpster, and someone snagged it. It was pretty bitchin', you know.  I almost kept it myself.

speaker: Martin
text: [_to Frasier_] You threw my chair away!  Are you happy now, it's gone!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_escorting Leo out_] Listen Leo, you have got to find that chair.  I don't care what you have to do.  Comb the entire building, search the neighborhood, just find my father's chair!

speaker: Leo
text: "Dump the chair," "Get the chair," "Find the chair," what am I,	the building lackey?

speaker: Frasier
text: YES!

speaker: Leo
text: Oh, okay. [_leaves_]

speaker: Daphne
text: [_softly caressing the chair_] Well, if no one's going to want this, we could put it in my room. [_sees Frasier and Martin glaring at one another_] Maybe later.  You two talk it over.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, this couldn't have worked out any better for you, could it?  You've been trying to get rid of that chair from the day I moved in here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you could at least show a little gratitude, I didn't do this for me, I did it for you.

speaker: Martin
text: Like hell! [_gets beer_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Geez, you're acting like I lost the chair on purpose.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, let me tell you something.  That chair was the only thing that made me feel comfortable in this house - that made me feel that maybe this was my home too.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, baloney!  Ever since you got here all I've tried to do is make you comfortable.  I don't even know why I bothered. I mean, everybody knows Martin Crane doesn't like calfskin, he prefers duct tape! _He seizes Martin's roll of tape, tears off a length and sticks it onto the new chair._

speaker: Frasier
text: And food crumbs! [_throws bowl of nuts onto seat_] There we are! [_takes Martin's beer_] And let's have a little dribble of beer while we're at it! [_pours can over chair_] Why not?  There, that's delightful!  Oh, and let's not forget - to top it all off - just the slightest bit of dog hair!

speaker: Martin
text: I suppose you're going to be throwing Eddie out by the dumpster next!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Dad, I don't know why you're carrying on this way.  We are, after all, talking about a twenty-five year-old, broken-down chair.  If you don't like this chair, I'll get you another one.  Any chair you want!

speaker: Martin
text: Really?  Okay, I'll tell you what chair I want.  I want the chair I was sitting in when I watched Neil Armstrong take his first step on the moon.  And when the U.S. hockey team beat the Russians in the '80 Olympics.  I want the chair I was sitting in the night you called me to tell me I had a grandson. I want the chair I was in all those nights, when your mother used to wake me up with a kiss after I'd fallen asleep in front of the television.  You know, I still fall asleep in it.  And every once in a while, when I wake up, I still expect your mother to be there, ready to lead me off to bed... Oh, never mind.  It's only a chair.  Come on, Eddie. _He exits.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene One - KACL, Roz's booth Frasier enters from the corridor._

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Fras!  How was your weekend?

speaker: Frasier
text: Hellish.

speaker: Roz
text: [_not hearing him_] Great!  Let me tell you what happened to me. See I had this most incredible date Saturday night.  It was really hot.  So Sunday, I'm driving home...

speaker: Frasier
text: Sunday?

speaker: Roz
text: I told you, it was hot.  So anyway, my car breaks down right in front of this church, and all the people are just coming out after the show...

speaker: Frasier
text: Service.

speaker: Roz
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Churches don't have shows, they have services.

speaker: Roz
text: Can I finish my story?

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, all right.

speaker: Roz
text: Thank you.  So, I walk up to the minister--is that all right?

speaker: Frasier
text: Mm-hmm.

speaker: Roz
text: And I ask him if I can use his phone.  And he tells me my sweater's on inside out.  One thing led to another, and we have a date tonight.  Ministers aren't celibate, are they? Not that I don't love a challenge.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know Roz, maybe you should take a sick day sometime, call into the show yourself.

speaker: Roz
text: You're on the air.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air_] Good afternoon, Seattle.  This is Dr. Frasier Crane. Now before I take my first caller, I'd like to make a personal appeal.  Last Saturday, my father's chair was taken from in front of the Elliott Bay Towers, and it's a runny split-pea green and mud-brown striped recliner with the occasional spot of stuffing popping out from underneath a strip of duct tape. Aas incredible as this may seem, I'm offering a handsome reward for its safe return.  Thank you.  And now Roz, who's on line one?

speaker: Roz
text: It's John... _DISSOLVE TO:  Scene Two - Time Lapse_

speaker: Frasier
text: So remember Stephanie, a little emotional flexibility is a good thing.  Just as the mighty oak snaps and falls in a windstorm, so the weeping willow bends and lives to see another day.  Thank you for your call.  So Roz, any update on the chair?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh yeah, the calls have been pouring in.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  And what are they?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, so far it's been spotted at the top of the Space Needle, in the Governor's Mansion, and a man on Lake Stevens said he saw it flying over his house, but he thought it was just a spaceship from a tacky planet.

speaker: Frasier
text: Funny stuff, people.  Well, let's just go to commercial break so you all can chuckle through these words from Yukon Lumber.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ingrates!  I dedicate my life to clearing away their psychic debris and this is how they repay me.

speaker: Roz
text: [_writing message_] Uh-huh.  Uh-huh... I got it.  He'll be there just as soon as the show's over, thank you so much. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: What?  What is it?

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, I found the chair. [_hands him a message slip_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, great.  Oh, thank God.  By tonight my dad will be safely back in his beer-stained, flea-infested, duct-taped recliner, adjusting his shorts with one hand and cheering on Jean-Claude van Damme with the other. [_trudges back into his booth_] Yes, it's quite a little piece of heaven I've carved out for myself, isn't it?  [_Roz's "tacky planet" line is strangely prophetic: eight years later, when the original chair was deliberately destroyed in episode[[_9.07_]](/frasier/transcripts/season_9/episode_7/bla_z_boy.html), "Bla-Z-Boy," the technical crew had a hard time finding the right material for the replacement they built, until one of them spotted it on an old set from the original "Star Trek."_] **BEST SEAT IN THE HOUSE** _Scene Three - A school stage, somewhere in Seattle The Chair has pride of place.  All around children are rehearsing, or painting scenery.  A child (Joey) dies on stage, rather noisily. A teacher (Mrs. Warren), looks on.  Frasier arrives._

speaker: Warren
text: Okay.  Okay, that... that was nice.  Um, but let's just remember there's a very fine line between good acting and hamming it up.  Let's try it again.

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me?

speaker: Brown
text: Mrs. Warren, I can't find my moustache.

speaker: Olsen
text: I can't remember any of my lines, Mrs. Warren.  Look, I'm really nervous.

speaker: Joey
text: Me, too.

speaker: Warren
text: Okay, people?  People?  Can I have you all over here for a second?

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, Mrs. Warren...? [_she waves him off_]

speaker: Warren
text: This isn't Broadway, it's junior high.  There's no reason at all to be nervous.  We're just going to go out there tonight in front of family and friends and have some fun, okay?

speaker: Warren
text: [_to Frasier:_] If one more thing goes wrong, I'm going to have to take my own life.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, if I could just have a word with you...

speaker: Warren
text: I'm sorry, in forty-five minutes the curtain goes up on a very shaky production of "Ten Little Indians."

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh, "Ten Little Indians."  I thought I recognized the mise en scene.  I did this play years ago. [_quotes_] "On the contrary, Major.  Many a psychotic killer would appear to be quite normal.  You see, you can never suspect that underneath that calm exterior there lies the heart of a maniac, ah-ha-ha." Happens to be true, by the way.

speaker: Warren
text: Who are you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: From the radio?  KACL Talk... well, never mind.  Listen, someone told me that my chair would be here, and sure enough here it is,  so I'll just get this out of your hair.

speaker: Warren
text: No, excuse me, but that doesn't go anywhere. [_confidentially_] Right now, this chair is the most entertaining thing on stage.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm sure that's quite true, but you see...

speaker: Warren
text: Don't worry about it, honey, just run along to the nurse's office, I'm sure you'll be fine.  They'll have you back here in no time! [_to Frasier_] I am so sick of being positive.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but you see, you don't understand, this chair belongs to my father and I must return it to him...

speaker: Warren
text: Sir?  You can have your chair back in two weeks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, you don't understand, I'm in a very difficult position here.

speaker: Warren
text: DIFFICULT?  You want difficult?  I have a set that's falling apart, a leading man whose voice changed at precisely three o'clock this afternoon, AND MY NAME IS SPELLED WRONG IN THE PROGRAM! [_calms down, to child_] See what I did there, Pomeroy?  That's the kind of anger I need from you in the accusation scene.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, I'll give you two hundred dollars, you can get yourself a new chair.

speaker: Warren
text: Forget it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, Mrs. Warren, I realize you are in an untenable position here, but I am speaking to you now from the heart.  You see, by putting this chair into the trash, I have wounded my father.  I realize it's just a chair to you, but to him it is a treasure trove of life memories that I have thoughtlessly discarded because I didn't like the way it looked in my living room.  I have sacrificed heart and soul for form and function.  Believe me, I am terribly ashamed of myself for that.  This chair is the last, best chance to forge any kind of meaningful relationship with the only father I'll ever have!

speaker: Warren
text: [_to children_] People, were you all listening to that? Because you can learn a lot from this man. [_Frasier looks proud_] That speech he just gave is a perfect example of the kind of hammy overacting I don't want to see out of ANY OF YOU FOR THIS ENTIRE RUN!

speaker: Frasier
text: Now just hold on for a minute!

speaker: Joey
text: Mrs. Warren?

speaker: Warren
text: What is it, Joey?

speaker: Joey
text: Bobby MacDuff just threw up backstage.

speaker: Warren
text: Perfect.  My Dr. Armstrong has opening night jitters.

speaker: Joey
text: No, it's not jitters.  It's stomach flu.  He's in the nurse's office.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, what else can you do?  You'll have to cancel the performance.  Too bad. [_pulling Chair off of stage_] I'll just take this along with me.

speaker: Warren
text: I can't cancel, I have three hundred parents in their cars already.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm sure somehow the American theatre will survive.  You can't do the show without Dr. Armstrong, he's too important to the plot.  I know, that's the part I played.

speaker: Warren
text: You played Dr. Armstrong?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes I... Oh, no-no-no-no-no, you're not thinking...

speaker: Warren
text: How badly do you want your chair?

speaker: Frasier
text: I-I'm sorry, it's out of the question!

speaker: Warren
text: You know, it would be a real shame if something... _She rips a piece of duct tape off the Chair, some stuffing gets pulled out with it._

speaker: Warren
text: Ooh! - _happened_ to this chair.

speaker: Frasier
text: But it's been years.  I hardly can remember any of the lines.

speaker: Warren
text: [_darkly_] Then you'll fit right in! _FADE TO:  Scene Four - Later That Evening The cast are taking their bows to much applause.  In the middle of the line is Frasier, towering above the children and wearing a large false moustache.  Mrs. Warren presents him with a bouquet of roses.  END OF ACT TWO_
